highlights.para: This chapter introduces you to the features and main components of the GNOME desktop. Before you start your first desktop session, read this chapter to familiarize yourself with the layout of the various features, and how the main components work. The desktop is very configurable, so this chapter describes the typical default configuration.

sect1.title: Introducing Desktop Components
sect1.para: When you start a desktop session for the first time, you should see a default startup screen, with panels, windows, and various icons. shows a typical desktop.

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of a typical desktop

sect1.para:
The desktop is the visible area of the screen, and everything that appears on the screen. The major components of the desktop are as follows:
Panels
Panels are areas on your desktop from which you can access all of your system applications and menus. Panels are very configurable and provide a place where you can access menus and applications in the way that you want. Two particularly important panels in are the GNOME Panel and the Menu Panel.
The GNOME Panel stretches the full length of the bottom edge of the desktop. The GNOME Panel contains the Global Menu button, which is a stylized footprint on the left side of the panel.
The Menu Panel stretches the full length of the top edge of the desktop. The Menu Panel includes textual rather than graphical menus. Click on the icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel to display a list of all open windows on the desktop.
Windows
You can display many windows at the same time on your desktop. You can run different applications in each window. The window manager provides frames and buttons for windows. The window manager enables you to perform standard actions such as move, close, and resize windows. You can work with many different window managers in the desktop. This manual describes how to work with the Sawfish window manager.
Menus
You can access all desktop functions through menus. The GNOME Panel and Menu Panel contain menus, so you can use a combination of menus and panels to perform your tasks. The Global Menu is your primary menu. You can access almost all of the applications, commands, and configuration options on your desktop from the Global Menu.
Desktop background
The desktop background lies behind all of the other components on the desktop. The desktop background is an active component of the user interface. You can place objects on the desktop background to quickly access your files and directories, or to start applications that you use often. You can also middle-click or right-click on the background to open menus.
Workspaces and viewports
You can subdivide your desktop into separate workspaces. When you start a desktop session for the first time, you have four workspaces. You can create more workspaces on the desktop, and subdivide your workspaces into viewports. You can switch to a different workspace, but you can only display one workspace or viewport at a time on the screen.
Nautilus file manager
The Nautilus file manager provides an integrated access point to your files, applications, and the World Wide Web. You can display the contents of your files within a Nautilus window, or open the files in the appropriate application from Nautilus. You can use the Nautilus file manager to manage your files and folders. You can also browse the World Wide Web in a Nautilus window.
Control Center
The Control Center provides an integrated access point where you can configure almost every feature of the desktop. To start the Control Center, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings . Choose the item that you want to configure from the submenus.
The most powerful features of the desktop are the high degree of configurability and the multiple ways that you can perform tasks.

The desktop provides interoperability of the desktop components. Usually, you can perform the same action in several different ways. For example, you can start applications from panels, from menus, or from the desktop background.

Your system administrator can make configuration changes to suit your needs, so that the desktop might not be exactly the same as described in this chapter. Nevertheless, this chapter provides a useful quick guide to how to work with the desktop.

sect1.title: Panels
sect1.para: You can create or remove panels at any time. When you start a session for the first time, the desktop contains at least two panels, usually the GNOME Panel and the Menu Panel. You can do the following actions with panels:

listitem.para: Create panels.
Delete panels.
Hide panels.
Add objects to panels.
Manipulate panel objects.

sect2.title: To Create Panels
sect2.para:
To create panels on the desktop follow these steps:
Right-click on a vacant space on any of the panels on the desktop to open the Global Menu.
Choose
Panel Create panel .
Choose the type of panel you want to create from the submenu. The panel is added to the desktop.

Except for the Menu Panel, you can create as many panels as you want. You can create different types of panel on the desktop to fit your own requirements. You can customize the behavior and appearance of your panels. For example, you can change the background of your panels.

sect2.title: To Delete Panels
sect2.para:
To delete a panel, right-click on the panel to open the Global Menu, then choose
Panel Remove this panel .

sect2.title: To Hide Panels
sect2.para: Except for the Menu Panel, each panel has hide buttons at each end of the panel. You click on the hide buttons to hide or show the panel.

sect2.title: To Add Objects to Panels
sect2.para: A panel can hold several types of objects. The panel in contains each type of panel object.

figure.title: A Panel With Various Panel Objects

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of a panel with various panel objects

sect2.para: You can add any of the following objects to all types of panels in the desktop:

listitem.para: Launchers

A launcher starts a particular application, executes a command, or opens a file. The toolbox icon in is a launcher for the Control Center application. A launcher can reside in a panel or in a menu. Click on the launcher to perform the action associated with the launcher.

You can create your own launchers for applications. For example, you can create a launcher for a word processor application that you use frequently, and place the launcher in a panel for convenient access. To add a new launcher to a panel, right-click on a vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu then choose
Panel Add to panel Launcher .
Menus

You can access all desktop functions through menus. The default panels contain menus, so you can use a combination of menus and panels to perform your tasks. To open a menu from a panel, click on the icon that represents the menu. To open a menu from the Menu Panel, click on the text that represents the menu.
You can create custom menus, and add the custom menus to your panels. The folder icon in is the default icon for menus that you add to panels.

You can also add standard menus such as the Global Menu to any of your panels. To add a menu to a panel, right-click on a vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu. Choose
Panel Add to panel Menu to display a submenu of menus. Choose the menu that you want to add from the submenu.
Applets

Applets are small, interactive applications that reside within a panel, for example the CD Player applet in . Each applet has a simple user interface that you can operate with the mouse or keyboard. The following applets appear in your panels by default:

Tasklist applet: Displays a button for each window that is open. You can click on a Tasklist button to minimize or restore a window. You can also use a task menu to shade and close windows. The Tasklist applet appears by default in the GNOME Panel.

Desk Guide applet: Displays a visual representation of your workspaces and your viewports. You can use the Desk Guide applet to switch between workspaces and viewports. The Desk Guide applet appears by default in the Menu Panel.

To add an applet to a panel, right-click on a vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu. Choose
Panel Add to panel Applets to display a submenu of applet categories. You can then choose the type of applet you require, then the specific applet.
Drawers

Drawers are sliding extensions to a panel that you can open or close from a drawer icon, as shown in . Drawers can help you to organize your work when you run a lot of applications simultaneously. You can place all the same functional elements in a drawer that you can put in any other type of panel.

To add a drawer to a panel, right-click on a vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu then choose
Panel Add to panel Drawer .
To open a drawer click on the drawer. To close a drawer click on the drawer again.
Special Panel Objects
Special panel objects perform functions that are generally not available through other panel objects. The lock icon in is the Lock screen special panel object.

To add special panel objects to a panel, right-click on a vacant space on the panel to open the Global Menu then choose
Panel Add to panel . You can then choose the specific special panel object you require.

sect2.title: To Manipulate Panel Objects
sect2.para:
You can manipulate panel objects in the following ways:
Move objects within a panel, or to another panel.
You can move any object to another location in the panel. You can also move an object from one panel to another panel. Use the middle mouse button to drag the launcher to the new location.
Copy launchers from one panel to another panel.
Drag the launcher from the first panel to the second panel.
Copy launchers from a menu to a panel.
Drag the launcher from the menu to the panel. Alternatively, right-click on a menu item, then choose Add this launcher to panel.

sect1.title: Windows in the Desktop
sect1.para: You can display many windows at the same time on your desktop. Each window has a frame. The window frame contains active control elements that you can use to work with the window.

sect2.title: Types of Windows
sect2.para:
The desktop features the following types of window:
Application windows
When you run an application on the desktop, a frame usually borders the window. By default, the top edge of the application window contains a titlebar with buttons that you can use to work with the window. The frame of an application window contains a button that enables you to close the window, or open the Window menu. The Window menu provides a number of actions that you can perform on the window.
Dialog windows
Dialog windows are associated with interactive desktop processes. A dialog window consists of the window frame and a single interactive pane that provides information and controls for the user. This manual refers to the interactive part of a dialog window as a dialog. The frame of a dialog window contains a button that enables you to close the dialog window, or open the Window menu.
You can use the Control Center to change the style of window frames.

sect2.title: To Manipulate Windows
sect2.para: You use the titlebar of an application window or dialog window to perform various actions with the window. shows a typical titlebar for an application window.

figure.title: Typical Titlebar for an Application Window

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of a typical titlebar for an application window

sect2.para: The active control elements of the window frame are as follows:

entry.para: Click on the Close Window button to close the window. You can also right-click on the Close Window button to open the Window menu.
You can use the titlebar to move, shade, and resize the window. You can also use the titlebar to change the focus of the window on the desktop.
Click on the Minimize button to minimize the window. You can also right-click on the Minimize button to open the Window menu.
You can use the Maximize button to maximize and restore the window.
To maximize a window click on the Maximize button. To restore the window click on the Maximize button again.
Click on the Shade button to shade the window. To unshade the window click on the Shade button again.

sect2.para: To change the size of windows grab the border of the window, then move the cursor until the window is the size you require.

sect2.title: To Give Focus to a Window
sect2.para: A window that has focus can receive input from the mouse and the keyboard. Only one window can have focus at a time. The window that has focus has a different appearance than other windows.
You can use the following elements to give focus to a window:

entry.para: Click on the window, if the window is visible.
Switch between the windows that are open with a shortcut key. To give focus to a window, release the keys. The default shortcut key to switch between windows is ModifierTab.
Choose the window from a window list in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Click on the icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel. A list of your open windows is displayed. Choose the window from the list.
Middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu. Choose Windows. A list of your open windows is displayed. Choose the window from the list.

entry.para: Click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. If the window is minimized, click twice on this button.
Open the Desk Guide tasklist, then choose the window that you want to give focus to from the Desk Guide tasklist.

sect1.title: Desktop Background
sect1.para: The desktop background is an active component of the desktop. You can use the desktop background to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: Start your applications, and open your files and folders.

You can add desktop background objects for convenient access to the files, folders, and applications that you use frequently. For example, you can create a symbolic link to a file that you use often, then drag the link to your desktop background.
Open the Desktop Background menu.
Right-click on the desktop background to open the Desktop Background menu. You can use the Desktop Background menu to perform actions on the desktop background.
Open the Root menu.
Middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu. You can use the Root menu to navigate between windows and workspaces.

sect2.title: To Open Desktop Background Objects
sect2.para: To open an object from the desktop background, double-click on the object. You can set your preferences in a Nautilus window so that you click once on an object to execute the default action.

sect2.title: To Add Objects to the Desktop Background
sect2.para: You can add desktop background objects for convenient access to files, folders, and applications that you use frequently. You can add objects to your desktop background in the following ways:

listitem.para: Drag the object from a file manager window to the desktop background. For example, you can create a symbolic link to a file that you use often, then drag the link to your desktop background. The icon for the link is moved to the desktop background. To open the file, double-click on the icon.
You can also drag files and folders to the desktop background. When you drag a file or folder to the desktop background, the file or folder resides in the /.nautilus/desktop directory.

Drag an application launcher from a menu to the desktop background. For example, you can open a menu that contains a launcher for an application that you use often, then drag the launcher to your desktop background. You can double-click on the icon to start the application.

sect1.title: Menus
sect1.para: You can access all desktop functions through menus. The default panels contain menus, so you can use a combination of menus and panels to perform your tasks. You can perform various actions on your menus, such as display the menu as a window and copy menu items to panels.

The Global Menu is your primary menu. You can access almost all of the applications, commands, and configuration options on your desktop from the Global Menu. Click on the Global Menu button on a panel to open the Global Menu . The Global Menu is represented by a stylized footprint, as follows:

Alternatively, you can right-click on a vacant space on a panel to open the Global Menu. Many of the menus that are available from the Global Menu are also available from the textual menus on the Menu Panel.
You can add as many additional menus as you want to any of the panels on the desktop. To open a menu that you add to a panel, click on the menu icon on the panel.

sect1.title: Workspaces and Viewports
sect1.para: You can display many windows at the same time on your desktop. You can run different applications in each window in the following desktop areas:

listitem.para: Workspaces
Viewports

sect1.para: You can subdivide your desktop into separate workspaces. You can display only one workspace at a time, but you can have windows open in all your other workspaces. You can divide your workspaces into subdivisions that are called viewports. You can display only one viewport at a time, but you can have windows open in all of your other viewports.

Workspaces and viewports enable you to organize the desktop when you run many applications at the same time. When your current workspace becomes crowded with windows, you can move your work to another workspace or viewport. You can also switch to another workspace or viewport then start more applications.

The default setup of the desktop is to use four workspaces and no viewports. Workspaces and viewports are displayed in the Desk Guide. The Desk Guide in contains four workspaces and no viewports. The first two workspaces contain open windows. The last two workspaces do not contain currently active windows.

figure.title: Workspaces Displayed in the Desk Guide Applet

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of Desk Guide applet

sect2.title: To Switch Between Workspaces
sect2.para: You can switch between workspaces in the following ways:

listitem.para: In the Desk Guide, click on the workspace where you want to work.
Depending on how your window manager is configured, you can drag a window across the screen edge into the next workspace.
You can middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu, then choose Workspaces. Choose the workspace that you require from the workspace list.

sect2.title: To Add Workspaces and Viewports
sect2.para: To add workspaces and viewports to your desktop perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Start the Control Center.
Select Workspaces in the Sawfish window manager capplet.
Use the Workspaces spin box to specify the number of workspaces you require.
Use the Columns and Rows spin boxes to divide the workspaces into viewports.

sect2.title: To Switch Between Viewports
sect2.para: You can work in different viewports or you can move windows from one viewport to another. Click on the viewport where you want to work in the Desk Guide. You can use the middle mouse button to drag a window from one viewport to another viewport in the same workspace.

sect1.title: Nautilus File Manager
sect1.para:
The Nautilus file manager provides an integrated access point to your files, applications, and the World Wide Web. To open a Nautilus window, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Applications Nautilus . The following figure shows a Nautilus window that displays the contents of a folder.

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of a Nautilus window

sect1.para: A Nautilus window contains the following panes:

listitem.para: Navigation pane
Enables you to navigate through your files and the online help system. This pane also displays information about the current file or folder. The navigation pane is on the left side of the window.
View pane
Displays the contents of files, folders, and websites. The view pane is on the right side of the window.

sect1.para: Nautilus enables you to do the following:

listitem.para: View files and folders
You can view your files and folders as icons or as a list. You can display the contents of your files within a Nautilus window, or open the files in the appropriate application from Nautilus .
Manage your files and folders
You can use Nautilus to create, move, copy, rename, and remove files and folders.
Customize your files and folders

You can add emblems to your files and folders to indicate particular states. For example, you can add an Important emblem to a file or folder to indicate that it is important. You can also customize folders in the following ways:
Add a note to a folder.
Specify a custom background pattern for a folder.
Specify a zoom setting for a folder.
Browse websites
You can use Nautilus to browse the World Wide Web. You can also bookmark your favorite sites.

sect1.para: Nautilus also creates the desktop background.

sect2.title: To Open Files From the Nautilus File Manager
sect2.para: To navigate to the folder where the file that you want to open resides, double-click on the folder icons in the view pane. When the file that you want to open is displayed, double-click on the file icon to open the file.

sect2.title: To Move Files Between Folders
sect2.para: You can move files between folders by opening two or more Nautilus windows. Open a different folder in each window, then drag the files from one window to the other.

sect2.title: To Navigate the Internet
sect2.para: You can use Nautilus as a browser to display websites. To display a website, type the URL for the site in the field on the location bar, then press Return. The contents of the site are displayed in the view pane. To reload the current page, click on the Refresh button.

sect1.title: Control Center
sect1.para: The Control Center provides an integrated access point where you can configure almost every feature of the desktop. The Control Center contains several dedicated software tools called capplets. Each capplet controls a particular part of the behavior of the desktop. For convenience, these capplets are grouped in the Control Center under the following headings:

To start the Control Center, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings .
Select a heading from the left side of the Control Center window. The capplets are displayed on the right side of the window. To open a capplet, double-click on the capplet.

sect1.title: Desktop Applications
sect1.para: The applications that are provided with the GNOME desktop share several characteristics. For example, the applications have a consistent look-and-feel. The applications share characteristics because the applications use the same programming libraries. An application that uses the standard GNOME programming libraries is called a GNOME-compliant application. For example, Nautilus and Control Center are GNOME-compliant applications.

GNOME provides libraries in addition to the libraries provided by your operating system. The libraries enable GNOME to run your existing applications as well as GNOME-compliant applications. For example, if your operating system is UNIX-based, you can run your current X11 and Motif applications from the GNOME desktop.
Some of the features of GNOME-compliant applications are as follows:

listitem.para: Consistent look-and-feel

GNOME-compliant applications have a consistent look-and-feel. GNOME-compliant applications use the look-and-feel settings that you specify in the Control Center. You can use the following Control Center capplets to change the look-and-feel of your GNOME-compliant applications:
Theme Selector, in the Desktop section
Applications, in the Look and Feel section
Dialogs, in the Look and Feel section
MDI, in the Look and Feel section
Menubars, toolbars, and statusbars

Most GNOME-compliant applications have a menubar, a toolbar, and a statusbar. A menubar is a bar at the top of a window that contains the menus for the application. The menubar in a GNOME-compliant application always contains a File menu and a Help menu. The File menu always contains an Exit menu item, and the Help menu always contains an About menu item.

A toolbar is a bar that appears under the menubar. A toolbar contains buttons for the most commonly-used commands. A statusbar is a bar at the bottom of a window that provides information about the current state of what you are viewing in the window. GNOME-compliant applications might also contains other bars. For example, Nautilus contains a location bar.

Some of the bars in GNOME-compliant applications are detachable. That is, there is a handle on the bar that you can grab then drag the bar to another location. You can drag the bar to snap to another side of the window, or to another part of the desktop. For example, you can detach the menubar, toolbar, and location bar in the Nautilus file manager.
Default shortcut keys

GNOME-compliant applications use the same shortcut keys to perform the same actions. For example, to quit a GNOME-compliant application, press CtrlQ. To undo an action in a GNOME-compliant application, press CtrlZ. You can also set the shortcut key for each menu item in a GNOME-compliant application.
Drag-and-drop
GNOME-compliant applications use the same protocol to implement drag-and-drop operations. Therefore GNOME-compliant applications provide consistent feedback when you drag-and-drop items.

The use of the same protocol also enables GNOME-compliant applications to interoperate in a sophisticated manner. For example, GNOME-compliant applications recognize the format of the items that you drag. When you drag a HTML file from a Nautilus window to a browser such as Netscape, the file is displayed in HTML format in the browser. However, when you drag the HTML file to a text editor such as gedit, the file is displayed in HTML format in the text editor.

sect1.title: To Find Out More
sect1.para: The desktop provides Help if you want to find out more about the following areas:

listitem.para: Desktop topics
Applets
Applications and utilities

sect2.title: To Find Out More About Desktop Topics
sect2.para: You can find out more about particular desktop topics in the integrated help system.

sect2.title: To Find Out More About Applets
sect2.para:
To find out more about a specific applet follow these steps:
Right-click on the relevant applet icon to display the applet popup menu.
Choose the
Help menu item on the popup menu to display an online reference manual specific to that applet.

sect2.title: To Find Out More About Applications and Utilities
sect2.para: To find out more about a specific application, start the application, then choose Help from the menubar.
